sub_topic: Calculating the enthalpy and entropy of inorganic reactions
message_1:
Calculate the standard enthalpy and entropy change for the reaction, given the following information:

2 H2(g) + O2(g) → 2 H2O(g)

∆H°f [H2O(g)] = -241.8 kJ/mol
∆H°f [H2(g)] = 0 kJ/mol
∆H°f [O2(g)] = 0 kJ/mol
∆S° [H2O(g)] = 188.8 J/Kmol
∆S° [H2(g)] = 130.7 J/Kmol
∆S° [O2(g)] = 205.2 J/Kmol

Assuming that all heat capacities are independent of temperature, calculate ∆S°rxn and ∆H°rxn for this reaction.
message_2:
To calculate the standard enthalpy change (∆H°rxn) for the reaction, we can use the following equation:

∆H°rxn = Σ ∆H°f (products) - Σ ∆H°f (reactants)

For this reaction, the equation becomes:

∆H°rxn = [2 × ∆H°f (H2O(g))] - [2 × ∆H°f (H2(g)) + ∆H°f (O2(g))]

Plugging in the given values:

∆H°rxn = [2 × (-241.8 kJ/mol)] - [2 × (0 kJ/mol) + (0 kJ/mol)]
∆H°rxn = -483.6 kJ/mol

Now, to calculate the standard entropy change (∆S°rxn) for the reaction, we can use the following equation:

∆S°rxn = Σ ∆S° (products) - Σ ∆S° (reactants)

For this reaction, the equation becomes:

∆S°rxn = [2 × ∆S° (H2O(g))] - [2 × ∆S° (H2(g)) + ∆S° (O2(g))]

Plugging in the given values:

∆S°rxn = [2 × (188.8 J/Kmol)] - [2 × (130.7 J/Kmol) + (205.2 J/Kmol)]
∆S°rxn = (377.6 J/Kmol) - (467.6 J/Kmol)
∆S°rxn = -90 J/Kmol

So, the standard enthalpy change for the reaction is -483.6 kJ/mol, and the standard entropy change for the reaction is -90 J/Kmol.
